SP.SPEAKER: G. Cost.
SP.P: A pretty civil young Man truly. I have known some squeamish ill-bred Fellows, refuse to do their Duty by a Woman, because she was in Years.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: But where hast been all this while; and what Busi∣ness dost follow?

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: As you see, I serve a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Are you Married?

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: My Master is a single Man, and won't keep any Body that is married in his Family.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Ay, Shame take these Gentlefolks; they would have every Body as bad as themselves. That must be a sad House, that has never an honest Woman in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: We live as they do in most Batchelors Families, very lovingly. While my Master is entertaining the House-keeper in his Chamber, I am as civil to the Cook-maid in the Garret.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: O sad, O sad! what pity it is that young Men should spend their Time unfruitfully with naughty Women; when, were they honestly married, they might in a lawful way do much good in their Generation. If you have any Thoughts of Marriage, I have a Widow in my Eye, that would do very well for you. She has something to bring you to, and is un∣der Thirty I assure you. While her Husband was in Health, she brought him a Child every Year; but I don't know how it fell out, he grew weary of her, and, as it is suppos'd, thought to have kill'd her with Kindness: but as it always happens in those Cases, he did his own Business instead of hers, he fell in∣to a Consumption—and dy'd about a Month ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: No, Goody Busy, that will never do for me; a wanton young Widow for a Wife, and a skittish Horse for a long Journey, are two the most troublesome things a Man can meet withal.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Perhaps you would rather have a Maid. Truly they are ticklish things, and I don't much care to meddle or make with 'em. But I do know of a Farmer's Daughter, that will fit you to a Hair. Her Father is a sufficient Man, and will stock a Farm for you. 'Tis true, indeed, she has had one Child; for I am a Woman of Integrity, and would not deceive any Body in these matters for the World. They did not marry her soon enough. But she'll make an excellent stirring Wife, I'll warrant her.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: A Maid that has had a Child, is worse than a Widow that's past it. I don't like any Body that you have propos'd half so well as yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Now out upon you, for an idle Pack. Why thou naughty, wanton, young Knave, what wouldst thou do with me? Heaven help me, I am old, and fit for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Let me ask you a few Questions, and you'll find you are fit for every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Well, come on then.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LI. Canst thou not weave Bonelace.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: Thou canst do Housewife's Work!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: Whip and stitch with a Jerk?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Yea, as well as any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: Canst thou not bake and brew?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: And do the other thing too?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Out, you're naughty: get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: Thou canst break Jests, and sing?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: Caper and Dance with a Spring?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.L: Yea, as well as any one.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: Welford, Silvia, Jonathan, Goody Busy, Goody Costive, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Come Neighbours, our Friends at Farmer Welford's expect us.—There is something of Consequence to be done; he would'n't send for us for nothing.—A Wedding, I hope; old Folks drop off apace, but if the young Ones would Marry, and be industrious, the World might still be increasing.
SP.L: By honest Love alone the World's upheld,
Death can't destroy so fast, as Love can build.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: I have obtained my Father's Leave to receive the Letter you have brought. Whether the Contents may require or de∣serve an Answer, I shall take Time to consider. I have no more to say.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: [Silvia gives the Letter to Welford, who reads it.]

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: See, my Silvia, the Picture of a Mind struggling be∣tween a Sense of Virtue, and the Love of Vice. Yet he entreats to see thee in such Terms, as might move weak Minds to pity him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: If Pity be a Weakness, I am, sure, the weakest of my Sex; but yet I fear to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: His base Attempt on thee, his avow'd Aversion to Marriage, and the Ruin of the Daughter of that honest Stranger whom we entertain'd, all shew the Justice of thy Fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: That Men should know Vice to be an Evil, by the Pain it gives, and yet cherish the Monster that destroys their Peace!

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: I have sworn never to expose thee to be again insulted by that licentious Man. Yet I cannot but wish he had not render'd himself utterly unworthy of thee. But I have given him up. You shall have ample Satisfaction for all the Wrongs you have suffer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: If you can entertain a Thought of Vengeance, how are you chang'd, my Father!

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Hereafter thou wilt know me better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: Whither have you sent the Stranger and his Wife? whi∣ther are you going with the People that you sent for? O Sir, forgive my Fears. Urg'd by your Love for me, you rush on to certain Ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Whatever becomes of me, you are the Care of Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: I never knew him transported thus before. He's going to Sir John, and will certainly provoke him to his Undoing. Instruct me, Heaven, what I shall do to save him.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LII. When Flora she had deck'd.

SP.L: O gracious Heaven, lend a friendly Ray,
To guide my Steps, in Darkness lost;
From Virtue's Precepts never let me stray,
But guide me safely thro' this dreary Coast.
My Love betray'd,
My Duty paid,
A spotless Maid,
Let me resign
My useless Breath, into the hands of Death;
For while I live there is no Grief like mine.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: A Room in Sir John's House. Sir John reading at a Table.

SP.L: 'Tis hard a rooted Love to dispossess;
'Tis hard, but you may do it ne'ertheless.
In this your Safety does consist alone:
If possible, or not, it must be done.
SP.P: A Poem on a Dwarf! what strange stuff is here! Hey ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: There he sits, poring o'er a Book, which he no more minds, than he does me.—Sir, did you call?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Who's there; Betty? Come hither. Why you look very amiable to-day, Betty.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: O Laud, Sir, you make me blush.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Betty, fill me some Wine. The large Glass, and fill it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My Love to you, Betty.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Thank you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Fill your self, and pledge me.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: He's coming about again, I see.—Your Health, Sir.—If he would but drink a few more Bumpers; for when he had drank most he always took most notice of me. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Leave me; and send the Lady that came home with me last Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.L: Sir, cou'd n't I—I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What is it you would say!

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Why, Sir, that, that,—I don't know where to find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Must I be plagu'd with your Impertinence too! go, send her to me, or leave the House your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: O Fathers! I can't bear it! I would I could send the Devil to fetch you both. [Aside.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LIII. In Kent, so fam'd of old.

LG.L: In vain, in vain I rove,
And if, to ease my Pains,

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Sir, I delivered your Letter to Mrs. Silvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: 'Tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You need give your self no farther Trouble to look for the Lady. I'll go and find her my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: How, Jonathan here! This Fool loves me however. I'll divert my self, by teazing him.—So Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: So Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Captain, methinks you look very scurvily after your last Defeat.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Now I think you look like a Dealer in Second-hand Goods, who having outstood your Market, repents, and wou'd fain be turning the Penny at any rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Ha, ha, how vex'd he is! but it would fret any Man, who going with flying Colours to take Possession of a Fort, should find the Gates shut against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Now you want to be attack'd, only for an Excuse to surrender. But you may keep your tottering Tenement 'till it tumbles about your Ears, for Jonathan.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Poor Fellow! I see he's horrible uneasy. But what Woman can deny herself the Pleasure of tyrannizing, when she has it in her Power? To be sure, Jonathan, you can never forget your last Disappointment.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LIV. There was a Knight was drunk with Wine.

SP.L: He seiz'd the Lass, trembling all o'er,
On storming bent, no Doubt, Sir;
But she slipt herself within the Door,
And the Fool was shut without, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: But soon repents she e'er said Nay,
And finds herself the Fool, Sir.
For she that wou'd not when she may,
She shall not when she wou'd, Sir. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.L: But Jonathan, Jonathan.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: But she that wou'd not when she may,
She shall not when she wou'd, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.L: But she that wou'd not when she may,
She shall not when she wou'd, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: O the impudent, pert, conceited Puppy! to leave me before he has had me! why he's worse than Sir John. I am like to have a fine time on't truly, between 'em both!

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LV. The Sun was just setting.

LG.L: How kind was I us'd, e'er this Lettice came here!
But to be refus'd, sure no Woman can bear.
By the Master forsaken, I'm scorn'd by the Man;
How was I mistaken in trusting Sir John?
For he kiss'd me, I grumbl'd,
But since that Slut's coming I'm left and undone.
But if I don't plague him for serving me so,
May I be worse tumbl'd, worse push'd, and worse jambl'd,

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XVI.
DIV2.STAGE: Another Room in Sir John's House.
Sir John, Timothy, Ploughshare, and Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Perhaps it mayn't be agreeable to the Lady, to be expos'd to gratify your Curiosity.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Sir, the Happiness of our Lives depends on finding our Child. And, as we are inform'd, she is here.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XVII.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir John, Timothy, Ploughshare, Dorothy, and Lettice Singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: My Father, Mother, and Ploughshare here! What will become of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Stay, Child; whither are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: O dear, dear Sir;—

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Ay, here she is; and no doubt but all the rest we have been told is as true.

SP.SPEAKER: Plough.
SP.P: Ah Lettice, Lettice, what have you been doing? You've spun a fine Thread truly. We shall have the whole Parish ring of you shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: O Child, you'll break my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Will she? but I'll break her Neck first.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: O dear Sir John, save me, save me, or I shall be torn to Pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Plough.
SP.P: How fine the Slut is! and how familiar with the Justice!

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Ay, ay, 'tis certainly so. Oh you impudent Carrion, I'll be the Death of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: To find my Girl ruin'd, is worse than never to have found her at all.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LVI. Hear me weep and wail.

SP.L: Welcome endless Grief,
Farewell my Goose and Sheers forever, ever.
Can I find Relief? No never, never.
For Grief, from Shame arising,
New Pains is still devising:
All Arts must fail,
Distraction prevail,
My Brain 'tis now surprizing—prizing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Friends, have Patience. What's past can't be re∣call'd, but I'm ready to make you any Satisfaction that's in my Power.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Look ye, Sir, you have utterly ruin'd the Wench. The Blame and Shame must now fall all upon her own Head; where∣as, had she been married, you know 'twou'd have fall'n upon her Husband's.

SP.SPEAKER: Plou.
SP.P: But who do you think will have her now?

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LVII. Send home my long-stray'd Eyes.

SP.L: Cou'd you return her true and chaste,
I'd meet her with a Bridegroom's Haste;
But since, from you, she's learn'd such Ill,
To hate her Spouse,
Or arm his Brows,
Keep her, for me, Sir, keep her still.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: O dear! what must I do? My Father will break his Heart; my Mother will beat my Brains out; and that Monster, Ned Ploughshare, will make me the May-game of the whole Parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Plou.
SP.P: Don't call me Monster: I'm none of your Husband: So keep your Tongue to your Self.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I won't; 'tis all along of you that this has happen'd. You always knew that I hated you, and yet you would have had me, whether I would or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Yes, Hussy, he would have made an honest Woman of you; but you must be a Gentlewoman, must you?

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LVIII. A Nymph of the Plain.

SP.L: So true, and so kind,
To whate'er you inclin'd,
To whate'er you inclin'd,
He had never deny'd;
But with Joy had comply'd,
To have made you his Wife,
And obey'd all his Life;
In a manner so soft, so engaging, and sweet,
As well might perswade you his Passion to meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Wife, I never approv'd of your forcing the Girl's In∣clinations, and now you see what it's come to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Friend, you seem an honest inoffensive Man, which aggravates my Remorse for having wrong'd you.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LIX. Young Philoret and Celia met.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.L: Regard my Tears, dispel my Fears,
I'll ne'er offend you more.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: The simple Groom, the Steed being gone,
So shuts the Stable Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.L: Pity my Pain. Tim. My Pity's vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.L: My Folly I deplore.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: Fame that's lost, and Time that's past,
What Power can restore?

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.L: Fame that's lost, and Time that's past,
What Power can restore?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What good-natur'd Man, that was but a Spectator in this Scene, but must be mov'd? I thought, 'till now, the general Love of Women consistent with Generosity, Honour, and Humanity.—False and destructive Principle! By this single Act of mine, how many innocent Persons have I injur'd? The Woman, too—the Easiness with which she gave up her Honour, makes her, tho' pitied, yet despis'd, even by me, the Author of her Ruin.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XVIII.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, Jonathan; whispers Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! Silvia, said you? Sure you mistake!

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: No, Sir; she's in the next Room, and desires to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Fly then, and conduct her in.—Good Peo∣ple, an Affair of Consequence obliges me to beg you would
leave me for the present. If you please to wait in the next Room, when that's dispatch'd, I'll send for you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: She's here, whom most I wish to see; and yet, such is the Power of Guilt, I dare not look upon her. Could I have thought her Sight wou'd ever give me Pain?—But, like a Wretch remov'd at once from impenetrable Darkness, in∣to the mid-day Blaze, I sicken at the cheerful Light, and fain would shun a Brightness, that glads all Eyes but mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: O Sir! pardon and pity an unhappy Maid: Had Heaven requir'd me to have dy'd, to have shewn my Duty to the best of Parents, the Pain had been far less; but filial Piety commands me to live, and interpose between your Power, and the Weak∣ness of my good, but incens'd Father.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LX. I'm Ormond the Brave.

SP.L: Your heaviest Resentment, ah! let me, let me bear.
In Pity to his Age, my reverend Father spare:
Toil, Want, and all you can inflict, I will not shun;
But when I think that he may be, for wretched me, undone,
Oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Welf.
SP.P: O Silvia! Never, 'till now, had I Cause to blush for any Act of thine.—Rise, nor offer that Incense to an Idol, which Heaven alone is worthy of, and which, were he not lost to Shame, as well as Honour, he must blush to receive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: Condemn me not: Can any Submission be too low to save from Ruin such a Parent? Still let me kneel.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Heaven, and all that's just on Earth, forbid it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Confounded and amaz'd, I had not Power to raise her from the Earth.—O Silvia!—Welford!—cou'd
you see my Heart! how deep my Contrition! how sincere my Sorrow! you would no longer fear, [To Silvia.] nor you be angry, [To Welford.] Vice, in all its genuine Deformities, I've just beheld. Virtue, in all its Charms, I see in you—Receive a returning Prodigal to your Arms; forgive, and make me happy.—Let the Priest, by honourable, holy Mar∣riage, give me a just Possession of thy Charms, and join me to Virtue, and to thee, for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: I came to beg your Favour for my Father, not a Hus∣band for my self. You once thought me mean enough to bar∣ter my Innocence and Virtue, for your Wealth; should I now consent to marry you, might it not be justly suspected that my former Resentment was not from the Love of Virtue, and Con∣tempt of Riches, but Artifice, to make the better Terms? Vir∣tue is Heaven's best Gift: Nor have they more than the Ap∣pearance of it, who submit to the least Imputation on their Fame, for Wealth, or Power, or Love, more tempting to a generous Mind. Think it not Pride in me, to refuse an Obligation to the Man who would have robb'd me, of all that distinguish'd me from the vilest of my Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: To have my Love and Admiration increas'd, by what gives me Despair, is a Punishment (tho' just) that's in∣supportable.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LXI. Minuet.

SP.L: With Pity, gracious Heav'n possess'd,
Taught Mortals how 'twould be address'd:
Celestial Fair,
O sooth my Care!
And, as my Heaven on Earth I view thee;
Lovely Creature,
Pride of Nature,
Teach me (like Heaven) how to wooe thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: I pardon, pity, and I love thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: O charming Sounds!—So Heaven cheers a de∣spairing Sinner, with the sweet Voice of Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: But Heaven, when it pardons, appears above Reward, by conferring Obligations. That is not in my Power.—To refuse them is, and in that I am determined.—Farewel, for ever.—'Tis hard—but Virtue, Prudence, and my Fame require it. Therefore, farewel for ever.—If your Return to Virtue be sincere, you have a Mistress who will ne'er forsake you; but, ever blooming, crown your Days and Nights with Joy,—when I am Dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Falling on Welford's Neck.] O Welford, Welford! must I lose her? You lov'd me once. Is there no Remains of Pity left? Can you behold me sinking, and yet refuse a friendly Hand to save me?

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: [Embracing him.] Heaven forbids me not to pity, love, and in the Anguish of my Soul, weep o'er thee, my now dearer than ever, tho' too unhappy Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Did not you call me Son? O that I were! To be your Son, is all the Happiness my Soul aspires to.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Too soon you'll find that Name includes the worst of Miseries, certain Despair.—But, to the Business of my coming.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XXI.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir John, Silvia, Welford, Goody Busy, Goody Costive, Jonathan, Betty, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Goody Busy, and the rest of my Friends who came with me, pray, walk in. Now let all here attend and witness to the Truths I am about to utter; and you, unhappy Youth, prepare to bear the most surprizing Change of Fortune, like a Man.—You are not whom you seem, and whom you think your self, Sir John Freeman, Baronet, and rightful Possessor of a fair Estate, but an innocent Impostor, and Usurper of ano∣ther's Right, and my unhappy Son indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil
SP.P: What can my Father mean!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: This is the strangest Story that ever I heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Welford, to invent a Tale so vile, and so absurd, to make me despair of Silvia, as being her Brother, is unwor∣thy of your good Sense and former Probity.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: I will not thank you for your Assent to the Truth of what I affirm. This excellent Lady is not my Daughter, but the much wrong'd Angelica Freeman, the sole surviving Child of the late Sir John Freeman, and Heiress to his large Estate.—I read Wonder and Surprize in every Face.—You look for Proofs.—Goody Busy, you serv'd Sir John Freeman's Lady, and my Wife, as Midwife.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: That I did to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: How many Children had each?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Two, a Son and a Daughter, I shall never forget it: they Lay-in both times together, and your Wife nurs'd both Sir John's Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: All this is true; but was there any thing remarkable upon the Body of Sir John's Son when born?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: No, but yours was mark'd under the left Breast with a bunch of Grapes, the Fruit, Leaves and Stalks all in their proper Shape and Colour, as if they had been growing on the Vine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Opening his Breast.] Here is the indelible Mark, visible and fair, as when the Seal of Heaven imprest it first, to distinguish the Impostor from the rightful Heir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Too well I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: If this Gentleman be your Son, how could his Birth have been conceal'd so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P:
That—with my own Shame, I am now to discover.—My Wife, while unmarry'd, attended on the Mother of this Lady, then a Virgin, and so far was she honour'd with her Confidence, that she liv'd with her rather as a Sister or Com∣panion than a Servant; after her Marriage to Sir John, and my Wife's to me, the Honour of their Friendship was continu'd; for I was happy in Sir John's, as my Wife was in his Lady's.—That we had the same number of Children, and of the same Age and Sex, and that my Wife was entrusted with the Care of theirs, you have heard already.—Soon after the Birth of this Lady, a War breaking out, Sir John, who had an honou∣rable Post in the Army, went for Flanders: I attended him thither, and (as I had formerly done) serv'd under him as a Vo∣luntier.—In this our Absence, a Fever made dreadful Ravage in this part of the Country.—Of it dy'd Sir John's Lady, and quickly after his Son, (who was then at my House) and my Daughter.—My Wife taking the Advantage of the Lady's Death, and our Absence, reported, that the Son who dy'd was ours; and the surviving one (truly ours) was Sir John's.—Our Daughter who dy'd was bury'd as his; and his, this Lady, was reputed and educated as our own—The Fraud was never so much as suspected by Sir John, nor any other Person, my self excepted—I indeed, by Observa∣tions, which none else had opportunity to make, soon found it out, and charg'd my Wife with it; she confess'd it, and to my Shame prevail'd upon me to conceal what I could never approve.—She dy'd before Sir John, and never liv'd to see her Son possess'd of the Honour and Wealth, which she by such wicked Means had endeavour'd to procure for him.—Thro' Heav'n's Mercy I hope she rests in Peace. But what have been my Tortures e'er since I consented to conceal the
guilty Secret!—Stung hourly with Remorse, I attempted to do her Justice and conceal my Shame, by effecting a Marriage between her and my Son; but Heaven, that refus'd the imper∣fect Satisfaction, and condemn'd the Fraud, has, you see, made vain the fond Attempt, nor would suffer her to receive that as another's Gift, which is her own proper Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And long may she enjoy it.—I have not so ill profited by her bright Example, as to repine at a Change of Fortune, so just, and so much to the Advantage of this won∣drous Pattern of all that's excellent in Womankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: Your Justice, and the Moderation of your Son, affects me more than these unthought of, undesired Riches: can I ever forget your more than paternal Kindness and Affection?

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Spare me the Confusion, that your Goodness gives me; look not so tenderly, nor speak so kindly, but treat me as your Injuries and my Crimes deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: The Crime was another's.—Your former Tenderness and present Justice, tho' to the Disadvantage of your Son, is all your own.—If you forsake me now, I am indeed an Or∣phan—Riches have Snares, and Youth without a Guide is expos'd to many Dangers—Be still my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Thy own worthy Father, were he living, could never love thee more.—But to be thy Father is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: This is your Son.—Let me be his, and you are still my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Do I indeed behold her heavenly Face, all clad in Smiles, and kindly bent on me? Do I indeed hear her har∣monious Voice pronounce me happy?—Or does my flatt'ring Fancy, to sooth Despair, form Images that have no real Ex∣istence?

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Bless her, bless her, Heaven! and as you have made her the best, make her the happiest of her Sex.—Never did I tast Joys sincere till now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: This surprizing Discovery unmade,—had I consented to have been yours,—the Disinterestedness of my Love and Virtue could never have been known.—Heaven has made our Duty and our Interest one. I may now without Reproach give my Hand, where before I had given my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: What, in Tears, Betty!

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: What have I lost for want of reflecting sooner? I'd rather have that Lady's Virtue, than her Beauty and Estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Poor Girl!—Why this is to have it.—I remember on a certain Occasion I made you a Promise of Marriage, if you think it worth claiming, give me your Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: There it is; if you can forget what's past, you shall have no Reason to complain of my Conduct for the future.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LXII. Ah how sweet's the cooling Breeze.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.L: Oh how sweet,
All over Charms,
To bless my Arms,
Thy generous Virtue all Vice defeating.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
With Transport unusual my Bosom is beating.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.L: Dearest Treasure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: O Joy beyond measure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.L: This truly is Pleasure.
Ye Follies adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: O Dearest!
All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
With Transport unusual my Bosom is beating.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Love gently firing,
And softly inspiring,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.L: Panting, desiring, I'll Virtue pursue.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Oh Dearest!
All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
White Hours approach, and the black are retreating.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Busy.
SP.P: Ay, this is as it should be—I could even cry for Joy, to see that there is so much honest Love left in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Reclaim'd by your Virtue, and restored to Fortune by your Generosity, I hope you'll take it as a Proof of my Sincerity, that I confess my self concern'd for the Distress brought upon an honest Man and his Family by my Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: Your Concern is just and generous, like the Man I hope ever to find you—but have I given my self to you, and not my Fortune? All is yours; dispose of it as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Jonathan, send Lettice and her Friends hither.—O Madam, the longest Life wou'd be too short to pay my Ob∣ligation.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XXII.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir John, Silvia, Welford, Goody Busy, Goody Costive, &c. Timothy, Let∣tice, Dorothy, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Unhappy Girl, I wish it was in my Power to make you ample Satisfaction for the Injury I've done you; but since that is impossible, I will settle something on your Father, in Trust for you, that, managed with Prudence, may secure you from the Fears of Poverty, the Rock on which you split before.—You, Sir, I hope will continue with us.—The Farm lately Tenanted by my Father, with your Consent, Madam, I bestow on this honest Man, for the Purposes before-mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: And may it answer your Intentions, which if it does, we may hereafter give 'em farther Proofs of our regard for their Welfare.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim. Dor. Let.
SP.P: Heaven bless you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Lettice, as I shall never see you more, take this Ad∣vice with you.—Keep this Lady's Example in view, and you may yet excell in Virtue many of your Sex, who having ne∣ver err'd in the manner you have done, look on your Fault as unpardonable.—Nor shall you, Betty, or Jonathan, be forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Jon.
SP.P: Sir, if you approve of it, Betty and I have resolved to take one another for better for worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That I do approve it, you shall find by the hand∣some Provision I'll make for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.P: Son, not foreseeing this happy Event, I sent for the Tenants to attend, that upon making the Discovery they might be ready to pay their Duties to this Lady, upon her taking Pos∣session of her Estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Madam, what think you of inviting 'em in, to par∣take of the general Joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.P: By all means.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR LXIII. Dutch Skipper.

SP.SPEAKER: Gaff. Gabb.
SP.L: Such Virtue possessing,
Includes ev'ry Blessing,
Ev'ry Blessing,
Our mortal State can know.

SP.SPEAKER: Wel.
SP.L: Such bright Examples firing,
Each gen'rous Soul inspiring,
Inspiring,
We scorn the World below.

SP.SPEAKER: Plough.
SP.L: With Pleasure while we gaze,
Transform'd, our Souls we raise,
For Virtue beheld the Mind renews.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.L: So the Sun, for ever bright,
Communicates his Light,
And adorns every Object that he views.
Since Truth to the Mind her own Likeness reflects,
Makes known our Defects, makes known our Defects;
Since Truth to the Mind her own Likeness reflects,
Let none the just Mirror despise.
What Virtue so bright but Reflection improves,
Or Folly so stubborn, but what it removes?
Reflect, be happy, and wise.
